choices.C: Assign User1 the Virtual Machine User Login role for VM1.
choices.B: Assign an Azure Policy definition to the resource group that contains VM1.
choices.A: Create a resource lock on VM1.
choices.D: Configure the Desired State Configuration (DSC) extension on VM1.

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription. The subscription contains a virtual machine named VM1 that runs SAP HANA and a user named User1. User1 is assigned the Virtual Machine Contributor role for VM1.

You need to prevent User1 from placing VM1 in the Stopped (deallocated) state. User1 must be able to restart the operating system on VM1.

What should you do?

discussion.content: No anwer is right - Create a custom role with Azure RBAC

Selected Answer: C
Read-only lock prevent stopping the VM but also restarting the VM

comments.content:
on the other hand the question is about OS, not about VM itself. 
OK, it is A

discussion.content:
I believe the answer is wrong:
A read-only lock on a resource group that contains a virtual machine prevents all users from starting or restarting a virtual machine. These operations require a POST method request.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/management/lock-resources?tabs=json

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Your on-premises network contains an Active Directory domain.

You are deploying a new SAP environment on Azure.

You need to configure SAP Single Sign-On to ensure that users can authenticate to SAP GUI and SAP WebGUI.

Which four actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Deploy Azure AD DS and sync back to Active Directory.
Create an Azure Key Vault service endpoint.
Configure SNC by using SNCWIZARD.
Change and deploy a logon file.

Express Route cannot be used to DIRECTLY connect On-premise to HLI.
Answer is A
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/hana-network-architecture

comments.content: ExpressRoute is a better option than ExpressRoute Global Reach in this case because it provides a private, dedicated connection between an on-premises network and Azure, which ensures the highest level of resiliency and security. With ExpressRoute, traffic never traverses the public internet, providing a more secure and reliable connection to SAP HANA (Large Instances). ExpressRoute Global Reach is used to connect two ExpressRoute circuits in different regions, which is not necessary in this scenario.

A. Microsoft introduced a new functionality called ExpressRoute Global Reach. Global Reach can be used for HANA Large Instances in two scenarios:

Enable direct access from on-premises to your HANA Large Instance units deployed in different regions
Enable direct communication between your HANA Large Instance units deployed in different regions

discussion.content:
Express Route Global Reach
Microsoft introduced a new functionality called ExpressRoute Global Reach. Global Reach can be used for HANA Large Instances in two scenarios:

Enable direct access from on-premises to your HANA Large Instance units deployed in different regions
Enable direct communication between your HANA Large Instance units deployed in different regions
Direct Access from on-premises
In the Azure regions where Global Reach is offered, you can request enabling the Global Reach functionality for your ExpressRoute circuit that connects your on-premises network to the Azure virtual network that connects to your HANA Large Instance units as well.

C is correct. (ExpressRoute enables connectivity from your on-premises network to Microsoft cloud services. ExpressRoute Global Reach enables connectivity between your own on-premises networks through your existing ExpressRoute circuits, using Microsoft's global network.ExpressRoute enables connectivity from your on-premises network to Microsoft cloud services. ExpressRoute Global Reach enables connectivity between your own on-premises networks through your existing ExpressRoute circuits, using Microsoft's global network.)

That's right, the proper answer is:
A. ExpressRoute Global Reach
C: Express Route is the correct answer

Ans is A.
ER without GR option can not route traffic from on-prem to HLI nets. 
For ER without GR option to route traffic from on-prem to HLI nets must be implemented transitive routing by means of reverse-proxy\IPTables\AZFW
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/sap-hana-azure-compute-network-storage/7-workloads-azure-large-instances-routing-considerations
and
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/hana-network-architecture

A. ExpressRoute Global Reach 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/sap-hana-azure-compute-network-storage/7-workloads-azure-large-instances-routing-considerations

Microsoft used Express Route to connect HLI to customer's VNet. 
So now going from the customer VNet to customer on-premises, it would be Express Route as well as it fulfills what is required. Express Route Global Reach when you are setting up a HSR from one HLI to another HLI sitting in a DR site. 

From MS docs --> "HANA Large Instances networks are isolated from each other for security. By default, instances residing in
diferent regions do not communicate with each other, except for the dedicated storage replication.
However, to use HSR, inter-region communications are required. ExpressRoute Global Reach, IP routing tables, or proxies can be used to enable cross-regions HSR.
"

SAP HANA on Azure (Large Instances) can be accessed only through Azure VMs and the dedicated ExpressRoute connection, not directly from on-premises

ExpressRoute Global Reach is the good answer, check the link https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/hana-network-architecture#direct-access-from-on-premises

Answer : ExpressRoute correct Answer, 

Express Route Global Reach is not correct option, Because ExpressRoute Global Reach. can be used for HANA Large Instances in two scenarios:

Enable direct access from on-premises to your HANA Large Instance units deployed in different regions
Enable direct communication between your HANA Large Instance units deployed in different regions
Answer is: A

What is the solution for this? 
A or C

Direct Access from on-premises
In the Azure regions where Global Reach is offered, you can request enabling the Global Reach functionality for your ExpressRoute circuit that connects your on-premises network to the Azure virtual network that connects to your HANA Large Instance units as well. There are some cost implications for the on-premises side of your ExpressRoute circuit. For prices, check the prices for Global Reach Add-On. There are no additional costs for you related to the circuit that connects the HANA Large Instance unit(s) to Azure.

One ER to you azure account and one internal HANA express route. These cannot be used to connect to HLI directly from on-prem. Global reach allows direct connectivity from on-premise by connecting these 2 ER circuits. Answer is A.

Connectivity between HANA Large Instance units in multiple regions needs ExpressRoute Global Reach, since the question does talks about connectivity between On-premise and HLI unit the answer should be ExpressRoute (C).

ER can be used to access SAP HLI from onpremise.

questions.question_text:
You need direct connectivity from an on-premises network to SAP HANA (Large Instances). The solution must meet the following requirements:
✑ Minimize administrative effort.
✑ Provide the highest level of resiliency.
What should you use?
questions.answer_description:
The Azure network functionality used is:
✑ Azure virtual networks are connected to the ExpressRoute circuit that connects to your on-premises network assets.
✑ An ExpressRoute circuit that connects on-premises to Azure should have a minimum bandwidth of 1 Gbps or higher. This minimal bandwidth allows adequate bandwidth for the transfer of data between on-premises systems and systems that run on VMs. It also allows adequate bandwidth for connection to Azure systems from on-premises users.
✑ All SAP systems in Azure are set up in virtual networks to communicate with each other.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/hana-network-architecture

questions.question_text:
You have an on-premises SAP landscape and a hybrid Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant.

You plan to enable Azure AD authentication for SAP NetWeaver.

What should you configure first in Azure AD?

discussion.content:
Correction.....The given answer B is correct

Azure AD Application proxy support accessing on-premise SAP HANA workload from Azure

App Proxy provides several security benefits including authenticated access, conditional access, traffic termination and outbound access.


https://download.microsoft.com/download/F/C/A/FCA51098-4F99-4C14-9DF7-45E338E72158/AppProxy.pdf

The given answer A is correct. ...Azure AD Application proxy support accessing on-premise SAP HANA workload from Azure

App Proxy provides several security benefits including authenticated access, conditional access, traffic termination and outbound access.


https://download.microsoft.com/download/F/C/A/FCA51098-4F99-4C14-9DF7-45E338E72158/AppProxy.pdf

A. a service principal.

To enable Azure AD authentication for SAP NetWeaver, you need to create a service principal in Azure AD. The service principal represents the SAP NetWeaver system and allows it to authenticate with Azure AD using OAuth 2.0. Once the service principal is created, you can configure SAP NetWeaver to trust Azure AD for authentication.
answers should be => A, C

Answer to second question is 
ExpressRoute fast path
To minimize latency the correct option is put the VMs on the same proximity placement group
Correct.
